channel.title: UK ISP Blocking TPB
channel.description:
[b]if you wish to still access TPB, use http://tpb.pirateparty.org.uk/[/b] [CENTER][img]http://static.guim.co.uk/sys-images/Guardian/About/General/2012/5/2/1335980084568/The-Pirate-Bay-008.jpg[/img][/CENTER] The filesharing website The Pirate Bay has been blocked to millions of UK internet users following a high court ruling earlier this week.
Customers of the country's second-biggest internet service provider (ISP), Virgin Media, were on Wednesday denied access to site. Other internet providers, including BT and Sky, are expected to follow suit within weeks.
Britain's ISPs were on Monday ordered to block access to the The Pirate Bay after the court ruled that it flouted copyright laws.
Virgin Media provides internet access to about 4.1 million cable customers in the UK, and more users who opt for its high-speed fibre-optic service. It has 21.5% of the market share, behind BT with 27.5%.
Customers for Virgin Media's rivals said they could still access the filesharing website on Wednesday afternoon.
The provider said in a statement: "Virgin Media has received an order from the courts requiring it to prevent access to The Pirate Bay in order to help protect against copyright infringement.
"As a responsible ISP, Virgin Media complies with court orders addressed to the company but strongly believes that changing consumer behaviour to tackle copyright infringement also needs compelling legal alternatives, such as our agreement with Spotify, to give consumers access to great content at the right price."
Source: [url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/technology/2012/may/02/pirate-bay-block-virgin-media]Pirate Bay blockade begins with Virgin Media | Technology | guardian.co.uk[/url] Court Ruling: [url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/technology/2012/apr/30/british-isps-block-pirate-bay]http://www.guardian.co.uk/technology/2012/apr/30/british-isps-block-pirate-bay[/url]

item.title: UK ISP Blocking TPB

[quote author=whattehp406 link=topic=543879.msg3989592#msg3989592 date=1336373553]
Yes the piratebay is wrong for not giving even more income to the CEO’s of warner and all those other companies, i understand how they make them a little less millionaire than they already are.
[/quote]Because all the millions of indies who lose income do not count… right?
[/quote]only scumbags pirate indie games[/quote]I don’t pirate indie games, i pirate the big guys like EA. And i don’t care if you think it’s wrong.

Read full topic

item.title: UK ISP Blocking TPB
item.dc:creator: @drubrkletern drubrkletern
item.description:
@drubrkletern wrote:

[quote=“Niall, post:32, topic:441208”][quote author=drubrkletern link=topic=543879.msg3990082#msg3990082 date=1336446720]

They seem to get away with the “we’re just a search engine like google, blame the uploaders” excuse.

it’s not an excuse though, it’s exactly what they do, they’re a search engine with links to copyrighted material, the only difference with google and tpb is google links to tpb linking to copyrighted material while tpb only links to copyrighted material

so, the only excuse is that google link to legal content and TPB link to illegal content?

… doesn’t seem like a very strong leg to stand on.

the point I was trying to make

tpb hosts torrent -> link to copyrighted material
google link -> torrent file hosted on tpb, hence google is linking to copyrighted material

granted hosting a torrent and merely linking to it is completely different, but if the end result is the same what is the difference?

I’m all for blocking access to copyrighted material but doing so by blocking 1 search engine(tpb) is the most asinine way of doing it

Wait, but its not technically the same though, I mean, without the person uploading/hosting the copyrighted material, would could the person linking you to the material get in trouble for?
Not sure if I explained that well enough but yeah there it is
[/quote]

generally it’s accepted that if you don’t upload the copyrighted material, or if you haven’t downloaded the copyrighted material then there’s nothing to get in trouble for

this court case ruled that thepiratebay was in violation of copyright law for linking to copyrighted content, something which in the future could be used to show that linking to copyrighted content (or say, teaching people how to get it) may also be in violation of copyright law[/quote]
I see

Read full topic

item.title: UK ISP Blocking TPB
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

oh god no! what a shame! if only there were 100s of other torrent/pirate sites out there and many methods to bypass shitty filtering!

item.title: UK ISP Blocking TPB
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“badger41, post:33, topic:441208”][quote author=Niall link=topic=543879.msg3990120#msg3990120 date=1336451979]

generally it’s accepted that if you don’t upload the copyrighted material, or if you haven’t downloaded the copyrighted material then there’s nothing to get in trouble for

this court case ruled that thepiratebay was in violation of copyright law for linking to copyrighted content, something which in the future could be used to show that linking to copyrighted content (or say, teaching people how to get it) may also be in violation of copyright law
[/quote]

inb4 youre taken to court because someone posts a link of a pirated song on your website[/quote]

well yes, if someone uploaded a picture of child porn, or linked to child porn on my website I could also be taken to court, it is my website and my legal responsibility to ensure it is within the law

of course lawmakers aren’t typically stupid and offer tools for website owners, one such tool is the dmca takedown notice, when issued, the host of the copyrighted content has to remove the content immediately, they can issue a counter notice if they believe the original notice was fraudulent and then it is up to the courts to decide who has the copyright to the material and decide the outcome, the dmca takedown notice provides a save haven for the host of any material so that they do not come under any legal issues should the takedown notice be observed, if they ignore it then they lose that safe haven status

Read full topic

nope, my isp seems to block any traffic to the servers tpb use

t4:

so they’re actually blocking traffic to known pirate bay IPs, lol!

yeah but there’s still ways to get around it (vpn and the such)

didn’t thepiratebay create a torrent of every magnet link they hosted? and wasn’t said torrent only a few hundred mb? I’m sure it’d be fairly easy to create a website which mirrors this info, or even better, hundreds of websites that do the same

MistaBigBoss:

Just change your DNS server noobs.

that doesn’t work, on virgin media at least

I’m sure some uk isps are just going to do a dns block but we’ll see

Mitko:

They seem to get away with the “we’re just a search engine like google, blame the uploaders” excuse.

it’s not an excuse though, it’s exactly what they do, they’re a search engine with links to copyrighted material, the only difference with google and tpb is google links to tpb linking to copyrighted material while tpb only links to copyrighted material

[/quote]Which is such a bad gap in the law, because it is incredibly obvious to anyone that their intention is to spread everything for free, regardless of being copyrighted or not.[/quote]

TorrentFreak – 11 Jan 12

Dutch ISPs Ordered To Block The Pirate Bay - TorrentFreak

Despite claims that freedom of expression is at stake, today a pair of ISPs have been ordered to block The Pirate Bay. Following a demand from Dutch anti-piracy outfit BREIN, the Court of The Hague ruled that Ziggo, the largest ISP in the...
